S3.T1.caption: Table 1:  Details of splitting the dataset.
references: We utilize ASCEND [20], a Chinese-English dataset for CS-ASR. We split the training set of ASCEND into three parts: Chinese, English, and Mixed (CS-ASR data), denoted as SC​Nsubscript𝑆𝐶𝑁S_{CN}, SE​Nsubscript𝑆𝐸𝑁S_{EN}, SM​I​Xsubscript𝑆𝑀𝐼𝑋S_{MIX} respectively. Our experiments only employ the Chinese and English subsets for fine-tuning the models and constructing datastores to keep the zero-shot setting. Additionally, we utilize the ASCEND test set (denoted as TEST) and the mixed training set (SM​I​Xsubscript𝑆𝑀𝐼𝑋S_{MIX}) as our test sets. The details of each subset are shown in Table 1.

S3.T2.caption: Table 2:  MER (%) of our proposed method based on the Conformer fine-tuned with  S C ​ N subscript 𝑆 𝐶 𝑁 S_{CN}  and  S E ​ N subscript 𝑆 𝐸 𝑁 S_{EN} .
references:
The evaluation results for the Conformer and Wav2vec2-XLSR baselines are summarized in Table 2 and Table 3, respectively. Our approach, employing the k𝑘kNN-CTC with a single datastore DA​L​Lsubscript𝐷𝐴𝐿𝐿D_{ALL}, as well as our method utilizing dual monolingual datastores DC​Nsubscript𝐷𝐶𝑁D_{CN} and DE​Nsubscript𝐷𝐸𝑁D_{EN}, outperform the fine-tuned CTC method across both baseline models and test sets.
Moreover, our integrated method, incorporating dual monolingual datastores with a gated datastore selection mechanism, demonstrates superior performance in all scenarios. This highlights that the utilization of the bilingual datastore introduces distracting noise during the retrieval process, which adversely affects performance. By implementing the gated mechanism to select a monolingual datastore, we effectively mitigate interference from alternate languages, resulting in precise retrieval and improved performance.
Our approach achieves a relative MER reduction of 4.4% and 7.4% on the T​E​S​T𝑇𝐸𝑆𝑇TEST and SM​I​Xsubscript𝑆𝑀𝐼𝑋S_{MIX} sets respectively for the Conformer baseline. Furthermore, for the Wav2vec2-XLSR baseline, we observe a relative MER reduction of 3.6% and 5.1% on the two test sets separately.

S3.T3.caption: Table 3:  MER (%) of our proposed method based on the Wav2vec2-XLSR fine-tuned with  S C ​ N subscript 𝑆 𝐶 𝑁 S_{CN}  and  S E ​ N subscript 𝑆 𝐸 𝑁 S_{EN} .
references:
The evaluation results for the Conformer and Wav2vec2-XLSR baselines are summarized in Table 2 and Table 3, respectively. Our approach, employing the k𝑘kNN-CTC with a single datastore DA​L​Lsubscript𝐷𝐴𝐿𝐿D_{ALL}, as well as our method utilizing dual monolingual datastores DC​Nsubscript𝐷𝐶𝑁D_{CN} and DE​Nsubscript𝐷𝐸𝑁D_{EN}, outperform the fine-tuned CTC method across both baseline models and test sets.
Moreover, our integrated method, incorporating dual monolingual datastores with a gated datastore selection mechanism, demonstrates superior performance in all scenarios. This highlights that the utilization of the bilingual datastore introduces distracting noise during the retrieval process, which adversely affects performance. By implementing the gated mechanism to select a monolingual datastore, we effectively mitigate interference from alternate languages, resulting in precise retrieval and improved performance.
Our approach achieves a relative MER reduction of 4.4% and 7.4% on the T​E​S​T𝑇𝐸𝑆𝑇TEST and SM​I​Xsubscript𝑆𝑀𝐼𝑋S_{MIX} sets respectively for the Conformer baseline. Furthermore, for the Wav2vec2-XLSR baseline, we observe a relative MER reduction of 3.6% and 5.1% on the two test sets separately.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4:  MER (%) of ablation study of Conformer and Wav2vec2-XLSR baselines on  T ​ E ​ S ​ T 𝑇 𝐸 𝑆 𝑇 TEST .  ⋆  indicates that p-value  < <  0.05 (compared with baseline and baseline with a single datastore).
references:
The results of the ablation study conducted on the Conformer and Wav2vec2-XLSR architectures are shown in Table 4.
Specifically, we conduct ablations on the utilization of a single datastore, two separate datastores, average n𝑛n neighbor distances for selecting datastore, and scale temperature t𝑡t to adjust the alternate language distribution.
For both models, k𝑘kNN with a single datastore improves the performance compared with the CTC baseline.
We can observe that k𝑘kNN with two separate datastores employing the shortest neighbor distances is unstable.
While applying the average of n𝑛n distances, it does improve the robustness of our method and achieve stable improvement on both baselines. Furthermore, the scale temperature t𝑡t has the most significant impact on the overall MER, adjusting the alternate language probability based on the accuracy of the gated datastore selection mechanism. Employing the gated mechanism with n𝑛n neighbors' average distances and scale temperature t𝑡t, we achieve the best performance on both datasets.
